math_problem.A3857: Determine all integers $ k\ge 2$ such that for all pairs $ (m$, $ n)$ of different positive integers not greater than $ k$, the number $ n^{n\minus{}1}\minus{}m^{m\minus{}1}$ is not divisible by $ k$. Instead of determining all integers at least 2 such that no difference of the specified powered terms between distinct bases up to that integer is divisible by it, simply find $s = k - 1$, where $k$ is the smallest integer at least 2 for which at least one such difference between distinct bases up to $k$ is divisible by $k$.

math_problem.A3861:
$2020$ positive integers are written in one line. Each of them starting with the third is divisible by previous and by the sum of two previous numbers. What is the smallest value the last number can take?

A. Gribalko
